comment.author: 25634864@N03
comment._content: Wonderful... I wish the roads around my town looked like this... the car has messed everything up...?!

comment.author: 31580040@N04
comment._content:
Compare this with the next photo in the photostream and note the differences.
The Lion Hotel has a list of what it sells and the licensee's name in this picture , only black panels in that shot. The flag poles are not on the buildings there, but have been added here. And significantly, the clock tower is now visible at the end of the road.
The clock tower was built in 1898 to mark the Diamond Jubilee of Queen Victoria in 1897. Its presence in this picture and absence in the next shot shows that that photo was taken earlier.

comment.author: 35234565@N04
comment._content: Thanks for your excellent detective work, Retired at last. The clock tower is the most noticeable difference by far, but it also looks to me as if the trees lining the street are more filled in in this image. Do you think that the flag poles were installed for the Diamond Jubilee?  We'll fill in some of the information you've provided the next time we update the records.

comment.author: 31580040@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/ryan_loc] I have no evidence but that is likely, re. the flagpoles. I agree that the trees have put growth on between the dates of the photos, but probably only a couple of years. If I've got the link right, maps.google.co.uk/maps?hl=en&tab=wl is the Streetview of the junction as it is today. The windows are the same but the corner has been altered. I don't know when that would have happened, but the style is not recent.
